title: Sitka Spruce (Picea sitchensis)
name: Sitka spruce
rationale: Random Forests best matched the range limitations of Sitka spruce along the coast of the Kenai Peninsula.
description: The Sitka spruce diagnostic species set consists only of Picea sitchensis (Bong.) Carrière. The area where Picea sitchensis is common and widespread helps define the Alaska Pacific vegetation region as distinct from Alaska-Yukon Southern or Alaska Southwest (see Appendix S3) because it is closely associated with wet coastal temperate rainforest. Several small, sporadic clusters of Picea sitchensis also occur on the west side of Cook Inlet and down the southern (Pacific) coast of the Alaska Peninsula. Picea sitchensis is one parent of the hybrid Picea ×lutzii Little; the other parent is Picea glauca (Moench) Voss. We included Picea ×lutzii within the white spruce diagnostic species set because it occupies well-drained sites that receive less annual precipitation than typical for Picea sitchensis. In the Kenai Mountains, where both species occur, Picea sitchensis is common in the immediate vicinity of the Pacific Coast (e.g., Seward) while Picea ×lutzii is common in the interior of the mountains (e.g., Cooper Landing).
